resource.chars:
he ranks between Lunulites and Millepora, among his "Polypiers Foramines":-
"Polypiarium lapideum, liberum, orbiculare, planum seu concavum, 
utinque vel margine porosum, nummulitem referens. Pori minimi,
adamussim dispositi, conferto, interdum vix conspicui". These bodies,
he says, are distinguished from <s>the</s> Nummulites by the opening of
their marginal pores, and by the absence of spiral arrangement
in their minute chambers or cells. In his second edition (1816),
he altered the name from <u>Orbitolites</u> to <u>Orbulites</u>; but the latter
designation having been previously employed in Malacology, the
first appellation has been restored by M Milne Edwards in his
posthumous edition of Lamarchk's work. Under one of the
designations <u>Orbitolites</u> or <u>Orbulites</u>, the genus has been recognised by Schweigger<sup>1</sup>, Brongniart and Cuvier<sup>2</sup>, Lamouroux<sup>3</sup>, Deslongchamps<sup>4</sup>,
Defrance<sup>5</sup>, Blainville<sup>6</sup, Bronn<sup>7</sup>, Goldfuss<sup>8</sup, Michelin<sup>9</sup>, Pictet<sup>10</sup>, and Dujardin<sup>11</sup>;
______________________________________

[<u>Note</u> 
1 Beobacht. auf Naturg (1819) pl. vi
2 Ossemens Fossiles (18  ) vol ii pl ii, p. 270
3 Expor. Method des gen. des Polypiers (1821) p. 44, pl. lxxiii
4 Encyclop Method, Zooph (1824) p. 584
5 Dictionn-des Sci. Nat., (`1825 vol xxxvi, pp 294.295.
6 Manuel d'Actinologie (1830) p 411 pl. lxxii
7 Lethaea Geognostica (1836.7) pl xxxv
8 Petrefacten (1826-33) vol i p. 41 pl. 12.
9 Icon. Zoophyt. (1845) p. 167 pl xlvi
10 Traité Elément de Paleontologie (1844.5) tom iv
11 Dict Univ d'Hist Nat. tom ix (1847) p. 162   ]
